snippet.textDisplay: I'm  still on the fence between the 77C9 and the Samsung 75Q90.  I planned on going wall mount at this size and the Q90 has the no gap wall mount and the fiberoptics cable... it will also do 120hz and I definitely won't need to worry about screen burn in three or four years down the road.  It's also $1500 cheaper.  decisions decisions
snippet.textOriginal: I'm  still on the fence between the 77C9 and the Samsung 75Q90. in the uk you can get a 55 C9 for around £1299 at the moment, Hughes does them currently (where i work reddith Branch). Even more strange my 55 C8 does work well when

in the uk you can get a 55 C9 for around £1299 at the moment, Hughes does them currently (where i work reddith Branch).  Even more strange my 55 C8 does work well when

snippet.textDisplay: Is there gonna be a point were stop improving on resolution? Like when we've gotten the most out of it and any more would be just wasted energy? I thought it was going to be 4k, but it seems the worlds turning towards 8k (and the other features we want/need out of panels still aren't fully rolled out it into 4k (120hz refresh rate, a minimum requirement for most gamers [This is isn't even touching on how hardware, while growing, is not growing at the pace of resolutions {It's hard to run certain software on 4k, much less 8k}]).
snippet.textOriginal: Is there gonna be a point were stop improving on resolution? Like when we've gotten the most out of it and any more would be just wasted energy? I thought it was going to be 4k, but it seems the worlds turning towards 8k (and the other features we want/need out of panels still aren't fully rolled out it into 4k (120hz refresh rate, a minimum requirement for most gamers [This is isn't even touching on how hardware, while growing, is not growing at the pace of resolutions {It's hard to run certain software on 4k, much less 8k}]).

snippet.textDisplay: I don't know about the US or Canada, but here in Europe, 65 inch C9 OLEDs can be had for as little as 2000 euros (and usually you can pretty much do US dollar = Euro for electronics pricing). On Black Friday, you could get them at that price AND get a 200 euro cashback, so only 1800. Meanwhile the Asus BFGD is still around 4000 euros... It's just no contest at all.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't know about the US or Canada, but here in Europe, 65 inch C9 OLEDs can be had for as little as 2000 euros (and usually you can pretty much do US dollar = Euro for electronics pricing). On Black Friday, you could get them at that price AND get a 200 euro cashback, so only 1800. Meanwhile the Asus BFGD is still around 4000 euros... It's just no contest at all.

snippet.textDisplay: Unfortunately, Linus is desensitized to pricing.
snippet.textOriginal: Unfortunately, Linus is desensitized to pricing.

snippet.textDisplay:
I recently got an 55" LG B9 for $999.99 couldn't imagine paying $5000.00 for what is basically the same TV but 77" vs. 55".. (Yeah I've save the $4000.00 and go with the 55" LG B9.. Regardless, the TV is awesome and certainly well worth the price if you want a phenomenal gaming, movie, and just all around great multimedia experience. The only thing that sucks is that the G-SYNC only works with current generation graphics cards (RTX or 16XX GTX cards). Pretty annoying marketing ploy but gaming still feels amazing hooked up to my GTX 1080 Ti@2GHZ - I7-8700K@4.8GHZ - 16GB DDR4 RAM@3600MHZ - etc...


Now just waiting for the new 2.1 HDMI and probably a 2080 Ti in the not too distant future. Wasn't planning on upgrading my GTX 1080 Ti but unfortunately I will need to do this to be able to use "G-SYNC". Currently I just adjust my settings to 120FPS locked @ 1440p so that "G-SYNC" is never really a factor. Also, when HDMI 2.1 is out 4K/120FPS sounds amazing but of course you got to keep in mind how demanding this is .. From what I've seen the 2080 Ti isn't really a 4K/120hz card but more like 60-80 hz seems to be about the norm for this card playing demanding games.
snippet.textOriginal:
I recently got an 55" LG B9 for $999.99 couldn't imagine paying $5000.00 for what is basically the same TV but 77" vs. 55".. (Yeah I've save the $4000.00 and go with the 55" LG B9.. Regardless, the TV is awesome and certainly well worth the price if you want a phenomenal gaming, movie, and just all around great multimedia experience. The only thing that sucks is that the G-SYNC only works with current generation graphics cards (RTX or 16XX GTX cards).  Pretty annoying marketing ploy but gaming still feels amazing hooked up to my GTX 1080 Ti@2GHZ  - I7-8700K@4.8GHZ - 16GB DDR4 RAM@3600MHZ - etc... 


Now just waiting for the new 2.1 HDMI and probably a 2080 Ti in the not too distant future. Wasn't planning on upgrading my GTX 1080 Ti but unfortunately I will need to do this to be able to use "G-SYNC". Currently I just adjust my settings to 120FPS locked @ 1440p so that "G-SYNC" is never really a factor. Also, when HDMI 2.1 is out  4K/120FPS sounds amazing but of course you got to keep in mind how demanding this is .. From what I've seen the 2080 Ti isn't really a 4K/120hz card but more like  60-80 hz seems to be about the norm for this card playing demanding games.

snippet.textDisplay: OMG.  I have this OLED C9LG77 inch TV model.... You will get use to the size after 1 month and wish you gone bigger!!!..   (But I cannot believe Linus manhandled this $5K display that way..... He must have money to burn!!..)..   BTW this TV is amazing; I have xbox one x, PS4pro, and a 4k HTPC connected to -> Hue sync lights -> Pioneer Elite Receiver -> C9 TV.   And I swear I its better than going to a movie theater (Plex 40TB 4k video stream local).... So.. If anyone has ever played COD/MW, Battlefield or any xbox one enhanced game with Ultra4K with 6 Phillips hue and 7.1 ATMOS surround; will either get flicker vertigo disorientation or  be amazed.   Im so glad I made this purchase.. !!  Linus you wont regret keeping this TV; but do not let your cat jump behind it because its so light... and its bottom heavy; but will, and can still tilt over if its not bolted down!!.
